reviewText:
Early Access Review

First impressions, played for about an hour. Pretty good for a £7 early access game.

PROS:
- Insane ship customisation, seems like 100+ parts (and this is only the first public release) some of which are decorative, utility, or weapons. You can have things like a sickbay, crew quarters, various armours, different cannons and propellors on a tiny or huge ship. Or you can glue a giant ♥♥♥♥ banner on the side of it.

- Pretty intense, epic combat. My eyes hurt from watching various cannon balls and shrapnel fly around everywhere, ships falling out of the sky and exploding on the ground, swashbuckling crewmates boarding enemy ships via flimsy ropes and watching your little guys run around inside your ships fixing things and dying. Amazing.

CONS:
- Although you build little defensive structures around your cities, they are basically just the same as ships except they can't move. No advantage really to investing in these, might as well build more ships.

- Battles seem to last about 45 seconds, even the largest ships run out of ammo very quickly and its annoying how often ships will just seemingly explode after taking one hit.

- Very limited single player campaign at the moment, just about 6 or 7 cities on a map which can be easily taken by 2 or 3 ships. I pretty much beat it in 10 mins.

- Picking certain things for your custom banner will actually determine which perks you get, meaning that you have to pick the icons for what perks you want, meaning you cant actually make the banner you want because you wont get the best perks. Don't really see a reason for this, just make the perks a seperate thing.

OVERALL , this game is really fun so far, the cons are things that seem like easy fixes to me (just rebalance ammo and add more defense structure parts) if you like games like Pixel Pirates or SPAZ, this game is for you. The simple pixel graphics might not be for everyone but if you can get past that this game has some potential.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It took me a while to work out why I find this game so fascinating but now I've got it:  the 'deep zoom' effect.

So what do I mean by this?

Level 1:
At the highest level you have a fairly typical, but stylish, campaign map that shows a birds eye view of the world, oceans, continents and islands etc.

Level 2:
Within these landmasses you have a number of cities each of which you can conquer and expand.  Click on a city and you are presented with side-on view of the city surrounds and any buildings, airships and landships located there.

Level 3:
Each vehicle has a distinctive, often animal like, shape and can have 'scary' looking warpaint.  The shape of the vehicle is a direct result of what it actually needs to successfully move and operate.  Nothing you see is pointless.

Level 4:
Now, zoom in to one of the vehicles and notice the individual rooms, with corridors and ladders connecting them.  It's like a little city within each vehicle.

Level 5:
Pick one of the rooms and zoom in further and you can see tiny men actually operating the weapons, transferring coal/ammo from stores, putting out fires, reparing armour, resting in berths, using repair rooms, controlling the vehicle etc.

Now realise each of these men is essential to the operation of the vehicle but can be killed in battle. Amazing!


Pros:

* Such an original game, there is nothing else like it.

*  Great feeling of controlling an empire of hundreds of fantasy war machines and thousands of poor little men needed to operate them.

*  Nice flexibiliy to play battles as a fast action game or a slower tactical game thanks to the time controls and spacebar to pause.

* Excellent feedback on what is actually happening during a battle thanks to 'speech bubbles' from your men when the vehicle takes damage, fires break out,  crew-members die, the battle is lost/won etc.

* If you don't like the built-in vehicle designs, design your own using the in-game designer and see if you can do any better.  You can also design and build static buildings (ie fortresses) and these are essential for defending a city.

* Really unique and stylish presentation style for an indie game.  The typeface, colour scheme, campaign map graphical design and UI style are all very well done.

* Music soundtrack is stirring and suits the theme of the game perfectly.

Cons:

*  Still in EA/alpha so there are a few performance issues with large battles, but the developer is aware of these and is looking to fix them asap.

* There are not many players playing multiplayer games at present.  I play single player only and love it, but if you need multiplayer you may want to wait to see if the community really grows.

* Some minor UI issues but these might just be my own preferences.


In summary, highly recommended.

The type of game you see video of and buy within the hour.
Also the type of game where you look up and realize it's 3 am. (I've played a lot more than Steam thinks I have.)

=Premise=
Engineer steampunk war vehicles and fortifications. Then make them fight.

=Execution=
Gameplay is simple and intuitive, yet deep, and already offers lots for players to learn and play with.

Building: Every part has pros and cons, and, as the designer, you can easily spend hours upon hours refining a creation to be sleek and efficient. Or you can make a giant wall of cannons. In addition, you can paint and decorate your creations to make sure they look good on the battlefield.

Combat: Exciting and fun (it's the big payoff after the building phase), though it can be a little clunky and buggy at the moment. (The game is still in alpha after all!) The combat system is quite deep, and well balanced with the building system. The compromises you make in the building phase absolutely define the tactics you use in the combat phase, though placement and use of terrain can also make or break a battle.

=Impression=
Already one of my favorite games to date, up alongside Minecraft and XCOM.
I can't wait to see it grow and mature.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Hugely enjoyable game with near unlimited replayability.

The art style is relatively simple but lends itself well to the game. The game shines in its mechanics and depth of detail (each crew member and is modeled with his/her own duties, ship systems such as coal, ammo and water run in real time, if you lose a significant portion of your crew certain systems will be resource starved).

The particle effects are amazing and it's so satisfying taking in the battle damage endured by your airship/vehicle in a smoke filled sky above the burning remains of your enemy.

Initally from youtube videos I was under the impression it was a turn-based game but this is not the case. It is very much real time. The cool down timer for giving commands to your ship (longer the bigger your ship is, can be shortened by adding bridge/cockpit modules) adds an extra dimension to battles where planning and preemptive positioning are rewarded.

The game has its rough edges but is supported by an active developer with plans for new features in the future such as adding monsters and random encounters in conquest among other things.

Conclusion: Great game with an enjoyable multiplayer. The community is small but once it grows it will be perfect.

I might be a little biased (I wrote the music for Airships: Conquer the Skies), but I will say that I have enjoyed playing this game ever since I first got a chance to try an early (pre-Steam!) copy. Designing your own Airships is a really fun experience, and seeing how well your ideas match up in real battles makes this game, at least for me, a very addictive experience. I’m still pretty bad at actual combat, but I’ve enjoyed trying to “out design” the enemy. I’ve always wanted to know what an RTS would be like if *I* could design the units, and with Airships, I get the answer.

Its worth mentioning that this is an Early Access game. I’ve scored a few of these games, and while I’ve seen a lot of customers who are really happy with Early Access, I know some people prefer to wait. With the pace that David Stark (the main dev) is updating Airships, I think we all see a promising future, but if you are looking for the final, complete Airships experience, you might want to wait. Having said that, the Airships that I’ve played on Steam is quite different from the Airships that I played when David Stark and I first talked about the score— this guy is serious about keeping the game updated, and working toward a solid, finished product. For me, Airships: Conquer the Skies is already worth a try, and I’ve had a fun time playing it, especially in its Early Access state.

I’m really proud to have been able to work on this title, and I’m excited to see it here on Steam. If it seems like something you’d be into, the price simply can’t be beat.

…I also hear the score is really good too :)

10/10 would write a score for this again.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Really fun and promising game that's in an excellent state for early access. Review after around 4 hours gameplay, and expecting to get a lot more out of it even at this stage.

Pros:

- Endless customisation! There are a lot, and I mean a *lot*, of viable combinations in airship design. Cannons! Flamethrowers! Bombs! Ramming! Boarding! Or a combination of them all. And of course there's the choice of a swarm of smaller ships vs several big behemoths, or, my current favourite, a group of cruiser-size ships with cannons and boarding that can support each other and go on if one dies.

- Decent AI. I'm finding the AI can use each different ship very well, with very few glitches for an early-access game. It's especially good at ramming, there's a good variety of AI ships in campaign mode, and I'm finding so far that each engagement still has the thrill of the unexpected. Although it's obviously a simpler game, I'm finding it refreshing after games like Rome: Total War 2 where the AI doesn't vary its units and is extremely easy to counter.

- A solidly functional campaign mode that should provide a decent few hours of fun.

- Online battles! Set a price limit, whether single ship only or fleet, and battle your friends.

- Pretty! For a pixel game it's really nice to look at and clearly a lot of love has gone into the campaign mode backgrounds as well as the ship combat.

Cons:

- Interface is still a bit fiddly. As far as I can see it's improved a lot over the last few updates, but it would be good to have something like a circle indicating how far boarders can grapple, better idea of what your boarders and guards are doing, and an empire balance sheet in campaign to find out where all your money is going. It has vastly improved recently in listing coal stocks, ammo stocks and so on, and the developer is paying a lot of attention to feedback so I'd expect the interface to continue to improve.

- Hard to find multiplayer games at this early stage. I can see it has huge potential for tournaments and leagues, though.

Honestly, trying to find any other cons seems like nit-picking at this stage. Airships: Conquer the Skies is enormous, evocative fun and, having been ground down by overpriced games like Civ 5 and Total War DLC, endless Dwarf Fortress clones and rude, terrible World of Tanks team-mates, this gem has made me feel really enthusiastic about gaming again.

Highly recommended.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Now this is what early access should be about.
Not unfinished sheit, but unfinished greatness with flaws.

http://youtu.be/qWytQCkLFP4

The game revolves around as the title would spoil to you, airships. *gasp*
Designing airships, building airships, flying airships, fighting other airships with you're airships, destroying enemy bunkers with airships, defending you're empire with airships and invading other empires with airships.

Did I mention the airships?

You can create almost anything with the tools you've been given, want a cheap ship with a bunch cheap guns? Rifle it up! If you want some more uumpf then cannons and bomb bay doors will do the trick.
Or if you are a brute you can just ram you're ship against the other ones.

Of course you can't build a ship with a ton of guns and ammo and expect it to fly very well without a bunch of lift and propulsion modules which you have to take into consideration while building them.
Crew is also important for everything from getting the ammo to the guns and operating them, or controlling fires and helping wounded comrades to the sickbay if needed.

The other limiting factor of you're imagination is naturally the cost of the airships and the bank vault of you're empire.
If you want bigger ships, then you must invade the other nations of the world and destroy the defensive buildings and airships stationed there. Which in turn makes the empire bigger and more cash come in from the newly acquired cities.

Be careful though! If you take your fleet into the enemy city and you yourself haven't produced any defensive buildings for the protection of you're citizens, the enemy can and will take you're city.
This way the game also has small strategical elements to it.

There is also a multiplayer mode but I haven't been able to try that as of yet, but I can imagine people coming up with all kinds of amazing airships to destroy one another.

Graphics are cute but at times its hard to make sense on what's going on because of them.

This is still in early access so if you absolutely don't purchase these things then don't but this game is in my opinion a diamond compared to other stuff that early access has given us.


So I absolutely do recommend this game even in it's incomplete form.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Great game, all around!

Airships is mostly a real time strategy game, with resource managing elements. I have not played the multiplayer very much, but the single player is some of the most fun to be had with 10$ that you'll ever find!

The graphics are neat pixel art, and available in a wide range of resolutions. Very crisp, though sometimes the colors can be a little bland (menus and such tend to be all brown or black, which is to be expected of the genre yes, but perhaps a little higher contrast would make things easier to see).

Gameplay is extremely solid. I've only encountered extremely mild bugs (a certain airship design never replaced the cannon when repaired, I had to refit it with one every time). You use the mouse to select commands for the airships (usually just movement) and this can seem simplistic at first, but quickly gets hectic once you start having more than 6 ships in a battle at the same time, which is by no means a bad thing! (protip: try to manuever your ships so that when one goes down, it doesnt take 3 others directly below with it, causing a massive fiery explosion destroying half your fleet).

sound deisign is spot on, weapons have varying sound effects that allow you to tell what is being fired by listening alone, music is good, though there's only like 3 different songs in the whole game. You don't really notice this though, as i'd liken it to the hangar building music in Kerbal Space Program; just sort of there, not really in the forground.

Some changes i'd love to see would be a custom sizing option for the menus, with the building menu sometimes it's difficult to select which module you want (at least on my 1080p screen, not sure about smaller resolutions). It would also be wonderful to see some more offline modes, perhaps having only a single airship and upgrading in order to complete tasks or something.
And finally, I would love to be able to personally change which workers do what, or at least assign them myself. for example, if I have 6 airshipmen, an ammo depot (4 workers max), two cannons (1 worker each) and a water tank (2 workers max), the game will automatically decide where the workers go. so i might have 2 workers on the water tank, two for the cannons, and two for the ammo depot. But sometimes i'd rather have 3 on the depot, and only 1 on the water tank. nitpicky perhaps, but it would help a little.

overall fantastic game, extremely enjoyable. Nothing glaringly wrong. Definitely a positive mark on the tarnished steampunk genre of games.

A incredibly fun  game with loads of options for airship/landship/fortess building.

I really recommend buying Airships, it is fun, it is quite cheap, and it has a really active developer.

A incredibly fun  game with loads of options for airship/landship/fortess building.

This game is a really great sandbox for anyone who loves airships, pixely explosions, designing death machines, and conquering lands with fleets of airships in all forms (and landships).

There is even a multiplayer, so grab a friend and challenge them!

Steam workshop support is also avaible for the newest dev build, so you can share your creations and create own weapons.

Unfortunatley it's quite unlikely that you will be able to play multiplayer with some random person, because few play it, but the conquest mode offers enough replayability for me.

I really recommend buying Airships, it is fun, it is quite cheap, and it has a really active developer.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is one of the best games I have ever played. I know, that is hard to believe, but hear me out. I was sceptical at first, but then I started playing it. Airships has as much depth as From the Depths, but is simple enough to learn in a few minutes. Here are my pros and cons. Remember, this game is very much in an alpha state.

Pros:
- Easy to learn
- Runs well
- Satisfying combat which never gets boring.
- Despite the pixelated visuals, it looks amazing. Not just due to its lighting and textures (which are good, but not outstanding), but its detail. If you zoom in on your ship, you can see crewman rushing around the ship, making repair, carrying shells to load into cannons, shoveling coal, and aiming and firing the guns. It is really amazing.
- Easy to use editor
- Sandbox for testing your creations
- Fun and simple overworld in conquest mode

Cons:
- Crashes frequently
- AI can sometimes be ridiculously overwhelming in conquest mode.
- Conquest has no diplomacy. You always are at war with everyone, no matter what. It could be great if you could establish alliances and trade. The conquest mode is also too short. If the pace was slower, it would help the game greatly. In conquest mode, it seems as if the only way to win is to buy as many cheap ships as you can, and then blitzkreig all your enemies. It takes away from the grand strategy portion.
- Game will not work without internet
Conclusion: Despite a few balance issues and crashes, it is definitely worth the buy. It is updated frequently, and I can't wait to see what David Stark has in store for us.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Excellent game, if you like Gratuitous Space Battles, you'll probably like this.
~No limits in ship design other than the maximum crew size.
~Partly controllable battles, with an interesting mechanic of control through bridges and cockpits on your ships. For example, if you have a cockpit for a giant ship, you might only be able to issue commands every 30 seconds, but if you have a bunch of bridges for a small ship, you can issue commands very quickly.
~Crew mechanics are interesting, your crew members can be wounded and then taken to a sickbay to recover. They also quite clearly move around the ship doing various tasks, such as feed coal into the engines, running engines, aiming guns, reloading guns, commanding the ship (from the bridge or cockpit), repairing the ship, defending the ship from invaders, and many more things (too many to list).
~A campaign thing that is a bit simple at the moment, although the dev is working on making it more interesting.
~Ship customization
~Realistic Heraldry, which affects your ships though some bonuses depending on what you choose.
These are just a few of the many good points of this game. The dev is very open about what he will be changing and adding to the game, he is also very active. One of the few indie games that has a dev who cares about their game.
Unfortunately, the community at the time of this review, is very small, almost no one plays the online gamemode at the moment, but I am sure if the community grew, it could be very interesting to see PVP.

There are many small things I would improve about this game if I could have my wish, but most of them simply boil down to wanting more of it. More modules, bigger battles, longer campaigns, more detailed tech tree, etc.

At the end of the day, it's a early access indie title that only costs $10 USD, so you have to be a bit realistic about what is possible. In that mindset it has a lot going for it:

1. I've not encountered any noticeable bugs
2. It runs fine on a laptop not built for gaming
3. Gameplay is fairly straightforward to learn and amenable to both casual and intense playstyles
4. Game balance is reasonable with multiple viable strategies
5. The developer is very approachable with plenty of interesting and attainable ideas for the future

Content-wise (as of v7.4), you're looking at about 15 to 20 hours worth of gameplay value for a singleplayer-only experience if you have only a modest interest in ship design. If you happen to have a friend or two for regular multiplayer sessions or happen to really love designing things just to watch them explode, I can easily see that going upwards of 40 hours.

------

Even if you're not convinced this is for you, it is worth watching for future updates. The game seems to only get better with age.

Here are some remarkable things about this game:
-When a ship breaks up (for example, from having its bow pinned on a floating island by one ship and having another ship come down on its stern, breaking it over the lip of the island) the part that is broken off becomes its own ship, albiet most likely lacking its own propulsion system or command staff (though not necessarily), thus putting it out of your control. This happens both when a ship is bisected and when it explodes into several large fragments.
-Marines and commandos have unbelievably good pathing for an indie game. You can have several ships in  row in deadlock with enemy ships (where your ships are equals signs and enemy ships are minuses: ====-----) and tell the soldiers in your rearmost ship to board an enemy ship, and the men will exit their ship, get on its roof and walk or jump along all ships in the intermediate distance (friendly and enemy) if doing so allows them to reach their target. If an enemy ground installation has an island directly above it preventing close access, you can position yourself above the island and your men can jump from your ship onto the island, and then from the island onto the building. The island isn't a static movement zone, just a piece of terrain that's loosely classified as a ship. Incredible.
-Ground walker mechs have highly adaptable footwork. I regularly see walker mechs climb on top of friendly and enemy landships in the course of movement, in fact this can be used to bridge otherwise impassible terrain. One time I saw a two-legged mech balance both feet atop a tree stump in the middle of combat.
-Anything can be built from tiny mail blimps and little interceptors to kilometer-long battlecruisers super heavy dreadnoughts with hundreds of visible men aboard (these are legal in multiplayer while playing 10k-limit games, it should be noted) from the same component parts (of which there are many, many).

As you can see this is an incredibly deep, dynamic and potent game. Because it can be hard to tell whether somebody loves a game or just enjoys tinkering with it in their own particular way, here is a list of well-known and excellent games I've played recently but had less fun doing so than I did with Airships:
Pillars of Eternity
L.A. Noire
Broforce
XCOM: Enemy Within
Prison Architect

I hope that Airships will become the low-key genesis of a famous AAA series to-be, similar to the relatively humble origins of Grand Theft Auto, Fallout, the Elder Scrolls and so forth. 10/10.

There are many small things I would improve about this game if I could have my wish, but most of them simply boil down to wanting more of it. More modules, bigger battles, longer campaigns, more detailed tech tree, etc.

At the end of the day, it's a early access indie title that only costs $10 USD, so you have to be a bit realistic about what is possible. In that mindset it has a lot going for it:

1. I've not encountered any noticeable bugs
2. It runs fine on a laptop not built for gaming
3. Gameplay is fairly straightforward to learn and amenable to both casual and intense playstyles
4. Game balance is reasonable with multiple viable strategies
5. The developer is very approachable with plenty of interesting and attainable ideas for the future

Content-wise (as of v7.4), you're looking at about 15 to 20 hours worth of gameplay value for a singleplayer-only experience if you have only a modest interest in ship design. If you happen to have a friend or two for regular multiplayer sessions or happen to really love designing things just to watch them explode, I can easily see that going upwards of 40 hours.

------

Even if you're not convinced this is for you, it is worth watching for future updates. The game seems to only get better with age.

Airships is an interesting game that combines RTS with engineering to make a unique battle experience. Creating different grades of craft for different situations prooves challeneging, as the conquest portion of the game, the enemy is always trying to one up you. It's an arms race to build the biggest guns first, but often creators need to think more than just about firepower. Budgets and requirements to keep a ship running shift the balance in the skies, and it is as much a puzzle game as an RTS when it comes to building.

This said, the game is still in Early Access, so there's a slight lack of content. The conquest mode doesn't last very long on any difficulty, and beyond these short campaigns, there is only the designer, non-campaign combat, and multiplayer. Additionally, it is worth noting that the campaign is very simplistic. Hopefully the creators will try to strive for additional content and game modes as the game becomes more popular. On the upside, this game is Workshop enabled, and people have already added a lot of fantastic content, so until there's more official stuff we have the brilliant work of modders to keep us busy.

Early Access Review

Airships is an interesting game that combines RTS with engineering to make a unique battle experience. Creating different grades of craft for different situations prooves challeneging, as the conquest portion of the game, the enemy is always trying to one up you. It's an arms race to build the biggest guns first, but often creators need to think more than just about firepower. Budgets and requirements to keep a ship running shift the balance in the skies, and it is as much a puzzle game as an RTS when it comes to building.

This said, the game is still in Early Access, so there's a slight lack of content. The conquest mode doesn't last very long on any difficulty, and beyond these short campaigns, there is only the designer, non-campaign combat, and multiplayer. Additionally, it is worth noting that the campaign is very simplistic. Hopefully the creators will try to strive for additional content and game modes as the game becomes more popular. On the upside, this game is Workshop enabled, and people have already added a lot of fantastic content, so until there's more official stuff we have the brilliant work of modders to keep us busy.

7.5/10
